Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South10th FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2630tamiment.wagner@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-05-01T16:12:16Description is in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
George Morris Papers TAM 200
1 Linear Feet (2 boxes)
1960s-1980s Materials are in English
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Helen Morris in 1997; additional materials were received from Helen Morris in 2001. The accession number associated with this gift is 1997.071.
Historical/Biographical Note
George Morris (1903-1997) was a long-time labor journalist, principally for the Communist Party USA's newspapers, the Daily Worker (national newspaper) and the Western Worker, their successor titles, and was also at one time head of the Party's National Labor Commission. Born to Jewish parents in the Ukraine, he came to the United States at age sixteen and was one of the founding members of the Communist Party USA.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; George Morris Papers; TAM 200; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Scope and Contents
This collection contains articles by George Morris and others, research materials, speeches and correspondence.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by George Morris was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

Labor unions and communism -- United States. Daily Worker (New York) Morris, George, 1903- Morris, Helen Bridges, Harry, 1901- -- |v Correspondence
Autobiography, 6 pp., 1981; Speech at Lenin 100th birthday conference; GM article, published in Soviet Contemporary; Letters to PDW editorial board, 1979-1986; Letters to Gus Hall, 1978-1986; Correspondence with Henry Winston, 1973-1986; "Letters" 1968-1984; "Correspondence" 1973-1985; including George Myers, Carl Winter, Mike Zagarell; Testimonial dinners 1970s-1980s; Articles and speeches on trade union matters circa 1979-1986.1968-19891Research material for American Labor: Which Way (1961); Harry Bridges letter, May 3 1971; Research material for CIA and American Labor: The Subversion of the AFL-CIO's Foreign Policy (1967); "Historical trade union materials," 1960s-70s. 1960s-1970s2
